issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2) incorrectly says "Each method takes a `Consumer<List<Note>>` parameter" while the context (and template/solution code) expects Consumer<List<Person>> for PersonController methods. This is an inner-artifact contradiction in the problem specification and can confuse students about the generic type they should use when implementing PersonController methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement wording to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>). This aligns the written specification with the template method signatures and the intended implementation for PersonController.

issues.description: In the solution repository, PersonController defines only a constructor with parameters (public PersonController(String baseUrl, Duration timeout)) but H05E01ClientApplication instantiates PersonController using the no-argument constructor (new PersonController()). This constructor parameter mismatch between the class and its usage will cause compilation errors and prevents the code from running.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide a no-argument constructor for PersonController (e.g. public PersonController() { this("http://localhost:8080/", Duration.ofSeconds(5)); }) or change H05E01ClientApplication to construct PersonController with the required parameters. Preferred fix: add a default no-arg constructor delegating to the parameterized constructor so the application code using new PersonController() continues to work and students are not blocked.
